60TH YEAR

Humphrey To Speak JHU Phi Beta Kappa Chapter
At Senior Assembly ToInitiate MembersNext
Week
Senator Hubert Humphrey (D.,
Minn.) will speak at the senior
class Farewell Assembly May 11 at
10:00 a.m. in Shriver Hall, it was
announced by co-sponsors Omicron Delta Kappa and the Student Council.

1
r

I

Sen. Humphrey, who has served
as a junior senator since 1948, is
, presently a member of the Senate
committees on Agriculture and
Forestry, Foreign Relations and
Government Operation..
Formerly, he was Professor of
Political Science at Macalester
College, 1943-44, and mayor of
Minneapolis, 1945-47. He graduated, Phi Beta Kappa and Sigma
Delta Rho, from the Denver College of Pharmacy and received an
A.B. degree from the University
of Minnesota and M.A. from the
University of Louisiana.
Processional To Open Assembly
Dr. Malcolm Moos, Professor. of
Political Science, will introduce
the Senator, who is currently a
Member and the past vice-president of the American Political
Science Association. The subject
of his address has
not yet been
announced.
A senior class processional will
Open the Farewell Assembly.
In a
form letter to the seniors,
class
president Mayer Liebman has
asked that at least 75 per cent of
the membership acknowledge
this
honor conferred upon the class by
Participating in the processional

Saturday Evening
To Feature Maisel

HUBERT HUMPHREY
and in the recessional.
Liebman To Relinquish Gavel
Welcoming remarks and an introduction to the program will be
made by Herb Belgrad, ODK president, and Liebman will then officially relinquish the gavel of seniority to the President of the Class
of 1956, Ray Garman.
Certificates will be presented by
Dr. Kelso Morrill, Director of Student Activities, to the Hopkins
seniors who were listed in this
year's "Who's Who in American
Colleges and Univesilies."
Music at the assembly will be
provided by the Hopkins Band.
The three lower class presidents
will issue communications to all
members of the student body urging them to attend this last assembly of the year.

Three SAC-proposed suggestions
concerning the reorganization of
the Cotillion Board were passed
last week by the. Board and two
Others are in committee hearings
now, it was announced by president Ron Nagler.
The Board passed the suggestion that the Student Council
Should set-up a calendar co-ordinating committee, should "work
With the Cotillion Board," and
should "support the Board's date
deadlines for social events."
Regular Office Hours
It also gave assent to the recommendation that the Board
Should establish regular office
hours for the purposes of giving
advice on social events. The office hours and the location of the
office have not been - determined
as of yet, Nagler said.
Finally, as a result of an SAC
suggestion, the Cotillion Board
Will mimeograph a set of
regulations for social events, and will
distribute a set to each organization that appears on its social
schedule. The list will include
rulings concerning tickets, and
dates and deadlines for making
up the social calendar, and will
name the members of the Cotillion Board.
Suggested To Abolish Tryouts
The two SAC suggestions that
are in committee hearings at present recommend, first, that the

replacing it with the interview

"Springtime," the DSRC-sponsored semi-formal dance, will take
place from nine to one Saturday
evening in the new dormitory
snack bar and adjoining patio.
Herb Kahler, chairman of the
Dorm Social Committee, explained
that, although couples will be
able to dance either in the patio
or indoors, all the tables will be
moved outside in order to take
full advantage of the better dancing surface in the snack bar.
Bill Maisel's eight-piece orchestra will provide the music. Tickets
for the dance, which is open to
the entire student body, may be
obtained from any member of
the DSRC at $1.50 per couple;
because of space limitations only
150 tickets will be sold. Refreshments will be served without
charge.
Said Kahler,"The DSRC anticipates a capacity crowd for 'Springtime,' which will undoubtedly be
one of the very nicest affairs of
the year. The decorations are exceptionally good, and, of course,
the snack bar is a beautiful room
even without decorations."
He explained that the bar will
be "trimmed with large floral
pieces and palms,"•while the usual
white lights will be "replaced by
soft, colored illumination." Outside on the patio colored lights will
be directed on a fountain, and
Japanese lanterns provide lighting.
According to Kahler, credit for
the "excellent" decorations goes
to Hector Van Lennep, head of
the decorations 'committee, and
his assistants, Wayne Warner and
Johp, Benaglia.

Three professors of history
have been granted leaves of absence for times within the next
two years, according to Dr. Sidney
Painter, chairman of the History
Department.
Dr. Frederic C. Lane will teach
a course in the general civilization program at Harvard for the
first term. His course in Fifteenth
Century Rennaissance will not be
offered here next year.
Dr. Gatzke Receives Guggenheim
Fellowship
Dr. Hans W. Gatzke, recently
appointed to a full professorship,
will travel to Europe next year on
a John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Fellowship. Mr. Robert Forster, who is expected -to receive
his Ph.D. degree here this spring,
will teach History 3-4 next year.
"Dr. Gatzke feels sure he will do a
good job," stated Dr. Painter and
added that a man who is known
is probably a better choice than
"grab-bagging outside." Mr. Forster has been a junior instructor
for at least two years and has
"done some lecturing"' in the
course. His field is the French
Eighteenth Century.
Dr. Spring To Study Fitzwilliam
Dr. David Spring will go to England the year after next on a Guggenheim Fellowship to make a
study of the life and times of the
Fifth Earl of Fitzwilliam. According to Dr. Painter, Dr. Spring
hopes to finish his book on the
general socio-economic status of
the British land-owning class of
the nineteenth century before he
leaves. No one has been definitely
chosen to teach History 1-2 in Dr.
Spring's absence.

SC To Hold Referendum May 16
On Newly Revised Constitution
Open -meetings of the Student
Council for discussion of the proposed Constitution will precede
a referendum of the document to
the student body May 16, president Lew Sank reported.
"At the meeting of the new
Council yesterday, a motion was
unanimously passed concerning
the passage of the constitution,
with the following reservations:
first, that the constitution will be
sent to all students by Monday,
May 7 with an accompanying letter explaining its major revisions;
second, that there would be a
minimum of ten days before voting on the constitution to allow
the student body to read and discuss the proposed revisions; third,
that the Council hold two open
meetings for the purpose of discussing the constitution with the
student body, one meeting being
at the dormitory; and, finally,
that the Student Council make
every effort to familiarize the
student body with the constitu-

the downstairs meeting room of
the new dormitory.
Referendum
On May 16, the referendum will
be taken to the student body, who
will vote on the revised constitution in the Gilman Hall post
office and at the dorm.
Sank explained that the constitution has not been revised
since 1946, and that the present
change was started in Jim Phinney's administration in 1954-55.
He enumerated the main
changes as being: "the inclusion
of the Gentleman's Code," and
the addition of the DSRC and
IFB presidents, the Honor Commission chairman "as well as the

Initiates from the Medical
school include Edward Reich,
James A. McFarland, James D.
Smiley, Charles C. J. Carpenter,
Franklin T. Hoaglund, and Louis
H. Schaffer.
Ph.D. candidates to be admitted

Miss Blanche Geer, education;
Alan H. Orrick, English; Daniel
E. Appleman, geology; the Rev.
Joseph A. Fitzmyer from the Oriental Seminary; Fernand D. Bedard, Johannes Severiens, and

The two faculty members also

Economy, and Professor David
Spring, History Department,
while Professor Erwin Panofsky,

The initiation will take place
May 15 at 6 p.m. in the Johns
Hopkins Club, and will be followed by the annual banquet, at

an address entitled "In Defense of
the Ivory Tower." Dr. Panofsky
Is "world famous" as an art -historian, according to Dr. Young,
who added that "we are lucky to
get him" as a speaker.

Peabody To Stage
Operas At Shriver
The Peabody Conservatory of
Music is staging today and tomorrow night three one-act operas,
"There and Return" by Paul
Hindemuth, "Hello Out There" by
Jack Beeson, and "Trouble in Tahiti" by Leonard Bernstein, at
8:00 p.m. in Shriver Hall.
The operas will be in English
and will feature Conservatory students directed by Felix Brentano
and the Peabody Orchestra, led
by Leron F. Evans. According to
Donald Spatz, public relations director for the Peabody, the operas
promise to be "gay, charming, witty and melodious."
"There and Return," starring
Jack Blaire and Myra Tate, is
built around action which progresses to a climactic point, whereupon time is reversed, and the
characters proceed backwards
through the events of the opera.

Selective Service Qualification
tests will be given May 17 at all
local draft board centers, Registrar Irene Davis announced this
week.
Any Selective Service applicant
who is a full-time college student
may apply by obtaining an application and Bulletin of Information, and a mailing envelope,
which he may get at any Local
Board, fill out the application
and mail it in at any time before
May 7, the deadline for applying
for this test.
The test is a three-hour written
examination which will provide
evidence for the use of local boards
in considering deferment of a
registrant from military service
as a student. Results will be sent
to the registrant's Local Board.

Four Resignations Necessitate
Election
The election was necessitated
by election to the Control Board
of three previous members and
by the resignation of a fourth.
Pete Putnam and Don McLeod
were also nominated.
The new members will hold office until the end of the school
year, as prescribed by the network's constitution.
Plans To Join Collegiate Network
Station Manager Frank Zampiello also disclosed the plan to
join a six-college network made
up of The University of Maryland, Annapolis, American University, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and, possibly the University
of Virginia.
Zampiello stated, "If all goes
well, we may broadcast a trial
period of two weeks at the end
of May. WJHU will originate a
half-hour program each week on
the Capital Network."
"Encounter"
He also said, "As for new programs, we have a fifteen minute
discussion program, 'Encounter,'
each Monday night at seven. The
Debate Council puts on a thirty
minute program, which we hope to
incorporate Into a series very
shortly. We have a brand new request show, a first for WJHU. Request boxes are located in the cafeteria and the dormitory Snack
Bar. The program, 'Yours for the
Asking,' is heard every ThursdaY
at seven."
He added,"We have had a series
of special tape shows including a
fifteen minute preview of the latest Barnstormer production, an
interview with Aldous Huxley, discussions with the Student Council
presidential candidates and a tour
of the Science Pair."
Guisseppe De Barber
Zampiello continued, "As for
plans into the more distant future, we are looking forward to
next year and are hoping to put
on a special Orientation Week
schedule of programs to include
introducing the freshmen to the
school and especially the town,
places to eat, the local movies, and
places to get a good haircut."
Also, the station is "hoping to
broadcast away football games
provided we can find sponsors."

Fulton And Pevsner
To Assume Places
On Physics Staff
Two new men will join the
Physics faculty as Assistant Professors next year, according to
Dr. Gerhard H. Dieke, chairman
of the Physics Department. •
They are Dr. Thomas Fulton,
who comes from the Institute of
Advanced Study at Princeton, and
Dr. Aihud Pevsner, from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Dr. Pevsner will continue his
investigations of high-energy particles by means of a technique
which utilizes a specially prepared
photographic emulsion to record
tracks made by the particles. He
will obtain his data using one of
the large machines in this country (accelerators, e.g., Brookhaven's Cosmotron) and carry out
his data analysis here. Dr. Dieke
explained that enough data could
be obtained in a few days to keep
a man busy for years and added,
"This field is in the forefront of
physics."
Dr. Fulton will carry out a theoretical study of high-energy phenomena and will probably work
with Dr. Pevsner in this field.
"Both men will teach," said Dr.
Dieke.,
Dr. Fulton received his BA.,
M.A., and Ph.D. at Harvard. He
was awarded a Frank B. Jewett
post-doctoral fellowship to study
at the Institute of Advanced Study
in 1954- and a National Science
Foundation fellowship to continue
his work at the Institute for '55.
Dr. Pevsner received his B.A., MA.,
and Ph.D. from Columbia. He is
at present an instructor in physics
at MIT.

A further "major' change includes a clause in the constitution
"providing for a hearing procedure so that the Council may better understand problems concerning' the area of non-academic

The new council members "are

the Council's reorganization.

NEWS -LETTER

HomecomingPlans
May Feature Jazz
By Eli Chosen Six
Os Steinwald, Jr., President of
the sophomore class, has communicated with Eli's Chosen Six, a
Yale University jazz band, concerning a jazz concert at Hopkins
on Homecoming Sunday, May 20,
and has found them "very anxious
to play."
Because the expense of the band
would be $260 and because it is
hoped that the affair may be free,
Steinwald is contacting the IFB,
the Cotillion Board, the Boosters
Club and the other class officers
in the hope of secuting donations
to eliminate any admission fee.
Also, there are plans of assessing
each fraternity $10.00 for the program, done through the IFB.
Steinwald has spoken with Dr.
G. Wilson Shaffer, dean of the
Homewood schools, who is withholding his approval pending
commitments from the groups.

What young people are doing at General Electric
FRANK V. SUMMERS joined G.E. in

1949 after receiving a B.S. in Chemical Engineering at Iowa State University the same year. He also graduated from G.E.'s Process Technology
program and other specialized courses.

Young chemical
engineer works
on new ways
to make silicones
Silicones are a new class of man-made chemicals with very unusual properties. Made from
sand,they assume the form of rubber,grease,
oil and resin. Under extremes of heat and
cold, the rubber stays rubbery, the oil oily.
Silicones added to fabrics make them exceptionally water-repellent. Silicone makes
waxes spread easier,..paints almost impervious to weather.
One of the men responsible for finding new
ways to produce silicone products is 26-yearold Frank V. Summers.
Summers' Work Interesting, Important
engineer of the Silicone Products
process
As
Department, Frank Summers first compares
the results of small-scale, pilot-plant experiments with the production methods in actual
use. Then, using* his own knowledge of
chemical-engineering principles, he designs
faster, more efficient and more economical
methods of producing silicone products.
Frank Summers' excellent training, diversified experience and outstanding personal
qualifications make him a valuable contributor to this engineering team.
25,000 College Graduates at General Electric
When Frank Summers came to General
Electric in 1949, he already knew the kind
of work he wanted to do. Like each of our
25,000 college-graduate employees, he was
given his chance to grow and realize his full
potential. For General Electric has long believed this: Whenever fresh young minds are
given the freedom to make progress, everybody benefits—the individual, the company,
and the country.

Educational Relations, General Electric
Company,Schenectady 5, New York

NEWS -LETTER

PAGE 'FIVE

Julian Huxley, Nobel inners
To Attend June Conferences

Lehigh University's trick drill team of Pershing Rifle Company
F-5, performs a non-too-perfect maneuver for the judges last Saturday on Homewood Field during the day long drill competition of
the Pershing Rifles' Fifth Regiment. Pennsylvania Military College
copped all honors in winning the meet from a field of 20 other
schools. The day's activities were topped off with a banquet and
a dance.

Eight IFB Greeks
To Donate Services
To Kids Tomorrow
Eight fraternities are participating in tomorrow's Inter-Fraternity Board Children's Softball
Tournament, stated Ron Nagler
IFB Vice-president.
Each fraternity has invited a
group of 10-12 year old boys from
various homes around the city to
spend a day as its guest. A run-off
tourney will be held in the morning from 9:45 until approximately
1 P.m. The winning group of boys
will receive an engraved trophy;
all clubs will receive small tro-

phies signifying their participation.
Interest Is High
Afterwards the fraternities will
invite their boys to the respective
houses for lunch. In the afternoon they may bring the boys to
the lacrosse game, or entertain
them in any manner which they
see fit.
Nagler stated that "the interest
has been running high." He added,
"I really appreciate the enthusiasm that has been shown by the
members of the IFB, and am sure
that we will have as much fun as
the kids."

from every disease which is

of the reconstitution of viruses
will be presented to the symposium by Dr. H. Fraenkel-Conrat
and Dr. Robley Williams of the
University of California's Virus

Dr. G. Stanley, who won a Nobel
Prize for work on the synthesis
of viruses, is expected to take part
in the ensuing discussion.
"The really important question
in this symposium is that there is
in the nucleic acid molecule which
causes it to show the mysterious
property of inheritability," Dr.
McElroy said. Three men from
England will join three biologists
from the United States in presenting this topic. After a presentation of the mechanism of the
cell's synthesis of the nucleic acids,
which are the acids involved in
the make-up of inheritable particles, the chemical structure of the
nucleic acids will be presented to
the symposium.
"This is one of the more exciting works in recent times—the in4

vestigation within a test tube of
the composition of these basic particles of heredity," Dr. McElroy
said. "We can't make a specific
nucleic acid yet," he said, but
he expressed the feeling of a definite possibility that this would
be accomplished.
Hopkins' Dr. H. Bentley Glass
will open the symposium's first
session, moderating the topic "The
Cellular Units of Heredity." "It
contains the presentations of several outstanding men, such as
George W. Beadle, the father of
bio-chemical genetics." Dr. Hans
Ris of the University of Wisconsin
will be among those speaking in
this all-day session. "The speakers were selected because they are
the individuals who are the experts on the topics covered," Dr.
McElroy stated.
The studies of the transforming
of one type of organism into another type has been studied extensively only in the past two or
three years. "Converting one
strain of organism into another
within a test tube is one of the
exciting new fields," he said.

Julian Huxley and several Nobel
Prize winners will be among the
scientists participating in the McCollum-Pratt Institute's symposium on the chemical basis of
heredity, which will be held here
June 19-21, Dr. William D. McElroy, director of the institute,
announced this week.
A great part of the symposium
will be devoted to the possibility
of "making" living viruses by
combining inert proteins and certain types of acids normally found
within a living cell but not possessing life in themselves.
Dr. McElroy stated that since
this process involved the apparent creation of life, he expects
the discussion to enter the realm
of philosophic definitions of life.
He said, "This is our seventh symposium, and I would say that it
will be by far the hottest."
Immunology Revolutionized
The ability to "make" viruses
could "revolutionize the field of
immunology in bacteriology," according to the biochemist. If a
virus could be synthesized which
was only slightly different from a
virus which caused a disease, and
then this man-made virus injected into a person, the person's
blood stream would buid up antibodies to protect him against the
disease-causing virus.

Lull In Schedule Jay Stickmen To Meet RPI
Seen Helping Frosh After Sinking Army At Point
Though in the midst of a two and
one half week break in the schedule, the freshman lacrosse team
Is far from taking a break in practice routine. Coach Wilson Fewster does not plan any let up.
In fact the baby Jays scrimmaged a couple of outside teams
of high repute this week, and
Fewster has two more scheduled
this week. He stated that he believed that the scrimmages should
more than compensate for any
games that would otherwise be
played, since the clubs he had arranged to scrimmage were even
better than those which the frosh
come up against in the regularly
scheduled games.
Fewster could not help but be
proud of the job the boys have
done this season. Thus far, the
yearlings have turned in a perfect slate of four victories. Even
in their worst showing of the present campaign, against Boys' Latin,
the opposition was able to get no
closer than seven goals. The Jays
took that one by an 11-4 margin.

Hofstra Hit Hard
The high spot of the season thus
far has been the Hofstra contest.
On a rainy day, with the first
string sitting out half the game,
Hopkins ran roughshod over the
visitors from Long Island by a
20-2 score. In their only other
games of the campaign, the freshmen came out on top of St. Paul's
and the Virginia freshmen.
Billy Morrill, former Friend's
School ace, leads the scoring
parade with 14 goals and 7 assists
for a total of 21 points. Mickey
Webster, Boys' Latin alumnus, is
a close second with 11 goals and 7
assists for 18 points; Bruce Duffaney, the third member of the
starting attack, has tossed in eight
goals, and assisted four others.
Low Scoring Opposition
Billy Powell is right behind Duffaney and leads the midfields in
scoring with seven goals and four
assists. Eddie Bernstein has five
goals and five assists to his credit
while Al Seivold has scored three
times and has been involved in
the
six other goals. As a team
sixty
recorded
has
Jays
freshman
tallies in four outings. Defensively, they have allowed only ten
goals to be scored against them
for an average of two and one
half goals per contest.
Fewster praised the club's offensive team work by the fact
that the scoring is so well spread
out. He commented that the outlook for the remainder of the
season looked pretty encouraging.
He further pointed out that 64%

of all the frosh goals have been
scored on assists.
Fewster Lauds Defense
Coach Fewster also stated that
"the defense is doing a good job,
but still has some work to do.
Many of the defense men didn't
have too much experience at the
opening of the season, .but have
come a long way since that time."
He lauded the work of John McNealey, Harry Nice, and Dick Leasure, a converted midfielder. Fewster is pleased with the work of
the two goalies, Emmett Collins
and Newt Kidd. "At present," he
said, 'Collins holds a slight edge."

Top Defensive Effort
"This was our top defensive effort of the season," commented
Scott. "Dick Watts, Bob Burgess
and Walt Mitchell held the Cadet

By Mal Levine
The last track meet of the regular season will be held tomorrow
with Western Maryland at the
Hopkins campus at 11:30 A.M.
John
Coach
Bridgers said,

have lost only to Gettysburg and
are strong in the hurdles, middle

relay in which two teams broke

Olympic Club who won the race
in 43.6 seconds.

who took second in the 100 yard

year 10 flat, Sam Wright, and

muscle but should be ready for
the Mason-Dixon meet. The Hopkins mentor also stated that Sutherland was looking better and that
Trenholm showed improvement.

season. Sam Liko collected three
nd Loren Cox garnered two of
'the Bird's hits.
Coach Ross Sachs commented,
'the Gettysburg game was the
orst of the season. It all started
n the first inning when they got

PalmerNewHead
Of Hopkins SDA

Darlene Graves of Cherry Hill admires the project that copped
first prize in Division I of the Baltimore Science Fair at Hopkins.
The fair was sponsored by the Hopkins in cooperation with the North
Baltimore Kiwanis Club. The winners will be sent to the National
Science Fair to be held in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, May 10 through
12. The project "Cationic Analysis of the Mouse" was prepared by
Jack Maniloff of Forest Park High School.

Theodore W.Palmer was elected
to head the Hopkins chapter of
the Students For Democratic Action for 1956-57 at a meeting of
SDA held last Monday.
Tony Adona was chosen as vicepresident; Turpin Rose as Secretary-treasurer. Palmer said of his
plans, "I intend to put out an
Issue of the Bulletin during Orientation Week; the membership has
to be increased in order that we
may engage in political action as
is our aim. I intend to make a
concerted effort to obtain new
members during
Orientation."
Palmer felt that the main concern of SDA should be civil rights,
but most of the activity of the
Hopkins chapter next year probably will "center around elections.
I feel that a liberal organization
at the present time must face the
problem of changing racial patterns in the United States and
attempt to see that the weakness
engendered by the present racial
tension is resolved."

Senator Hubert Humphrey (D.,

class Farewell Assembly May 11 at

Sen. Humphrey, who has served
as a junior senator since 1948, is
, presently a member of the Senate
committees on Agriculture and
Forestry, Foreign Relations and
Government Operation..

College, 1943-44, and mayor of
Minneapolis, 1945-47. He graduated, Phi Beta Kappa and Sigma
Delta Rho, from the Denver College of Pharmacy and received an
A.B. degree from the University
of Minnesota and M.A. from the
University of Louisiana.

Political Science, will introduce
the Senator, who is currently a
Member and the past vice-president of the American Political
Science Association. The subject
of his address has
not yet been
announced.

Open the Farewell Assembly.

form letter to the seniors,
class
president Mayer Liebman has

the membership acknowledge
this
honor conferred upon the class by
Participating in the processional

of 1956, Ray Garman.
Certificates will be presented by

seniors who were listed in this
year's "Who's Who in American
Colleges and Univesilies."
Music at the assembly will be
provided by the Hopkins Band.
The three lower class presidents
will issue communications to all
members of the student body urging them to attend this last assembly of the year.

"Springtime," the DSRC-sponsored semi-formal dance, will take
place from nine to one Saturday
evening in the new dormitory
snack bar and adjoining patio.
Herb Kahler, chairman of the
Dorm Social Committee, explained
that, although couples will be
able to dance either in the patio
or indoors, all the tables will be
moved outside in order to take
full advantage of the better dancing surface in the snack bar.
Bill Maisel's eight-piece orchestra will provide the music. Tickets
for the dance, which is open to
the entire student body, may be
obtained from any member of
the DSRC at $1.50 per couple;
because of space limitations only
150 tickets will be sold. Refreshments will be served without
charge.
Said Kahler,"The DSRC anticipates a capacity crowd for 'Springtime,' which will undoubtedly be
one of the very nicest affairs of
the year. The decorations are exceptionally good, and, of course,
the snack bar is a beautiful room
even without decorations."
He explained that the bar will
be "trimmed with large floral
pieces and palms,"•while the usual
white lights will be "replaced by
soft, colored illumination." Outside on the patio colored lights will
be directed on a fountain, and
Japanese lanterns provide lighting.
According to Kahler, credit for
the "excellent" decorations goes
to Hector Van Lennep, head of
the decorations 'committee, and
his assistants, Wayne Warner and
Johp, Benaglia.

Three professors of history
have been granted leaves of absence for times within the next
two years, according to Dr. Sidney
Painter, chairman of the History
Department.
Dr. Frederic C. Lane will teach
a course in the general civilization program at Harvard for the
first term. His course in Fifteenth
Century Rennaissance will not be
offered here next year.
Dr. Gatzke Receives Guggenheim
Fellowship
Dr. Hans W. Gatzke, recently
appointed to a full professorship,
will travel to Europe next year on
a John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Fellowship. Mr. Robert Forster, who is expected -to receive
his Ph.D. degree here this spring,
will teach History 3-4 next year.
"Dr. Gatzke feels sure he will do a
good job," stated Dr. Painter and
added that a man who is known
is probably a better choice than
"grab-bagging outside." Mr. Forster has been a junior instructor
for at least two years and has
"done some lecturing"' in the
course. His field is the French
Eighteenth Century.
Dr. Spring To Study Fitzwilliam
Dr. David Spring will go to England the year after next on a Guggenheim Fellowship to make a
study of the life and times of the
Fifth Earl of Fitzwilliam. According to Dr. Painter, Dr. Spring
hopes to finish his book on the
general socio-economic status of
the British land-owning class of
the nineteenth century before he
leaves. No one has been definitely
chosen to teach History 1-2 in Dr.
Spring's absence.

Peabody To Stage
Operas At Shriver
The Peabody Conservatory of
Music is staging today and tomorrow night three one-act operas,
"There and Return" by Paul
Hindemuth, "Hello Out There" by
Jack Beeson, and "Trouble in Tahiti" by Leonard Bernstein, at
8:00 p.m. in Shriver Hall.
The operas will be in English
and will feature Conservatory students directed by Felix Brentano
and the Peabody Orchestra, led
by Leron F. Evans. According to
Donald Spatz, public relations director for the Peabody, the operas
promise to be "gay, charming, witty and melodious."
"There and Return," starring
Jack Blaire and Myra Tate, is
built around action which progresses to a climactic point, whereupon time is reversed, and the
characters proceed backwards
through the events of the opera.

Selective Service Qualification
tests will be given May 17 at all
local draft board centers, Registrar Irene Davis announced this
week.
Any Selective Service applicant
who is a full-time college student
may apply by obtaining an application and Bulletin of Information, and a mailing envelope,
which he may get at any Local
Board, fill out the application
and mail it in at any time before

Four Resignations Necessitate
Election
The election was necessitated
by election to the Control Board
of three previous members and
by the resignation of a fourth.
Pete Putnam and Don McLeod
were also nominated.
The new members will hold office until the end of the school
year, as prescribed by the network's constitution.
Plans To Join Collegiate Network
Station Manager Frank Zampiello also disclosed the plan to
join a six-college network made
up of The University of Maryland, Annapolis, American University, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and, possibly the University
of Virginia.
Zampiello stated, "If all goes
well, we may broadcast a trial
period of two weeks at the end
of May. WJHU will originate a
half-hour program each week on
the Capital Network."
"Encounter"
He also said, "As for new programs, we have a fifteen minute
discussion program, 'Encounter,'
each Monday night at seven. The
Debate Council puts on a thirty
minute program, which we hope to
incorporate Into a series very
shortly. We have a brand new request show, a first for WJHU. Request boxes are located in the cafeteria and the dormitory Snack
Bar. The program, 'Yours for the
Asking,' is heard every ThursdaY
at seven."
He added,"We have had a series
of special tape shows including a
fifteen minute preview of the latest Barnstormer production, an
interview with Aldous Huxley, discussions with the Student Council
presidential candidates and a tour
of the Science Pair."

schedule of programs to include
introducing the freshmen to the
school and especially the town,
places to eat, the local movies, and
places to get a good haircut."
Also, the station is "hoping to
broadcast away football games
provided we can find sponsors."

Advanced Study at Princeton, and
Dr. Aihud Pevsner, from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Dr. Pevsner will continue his
investigations of high-energy particles by means of a technique
which utilizes a specially prepared
photographic emulsion to record
tracks made by the particles. He
will obtain his data using one of
the large machines in this country (accelerators, e.g., Brookhaven's Cosmotron) and carry out
his data analysis here. Dr. Dieke
explained that enough data could
be obtained in a few days to keep
a man busy for years and added,
"This field is in the forefront of
physics."
Dr. Fulton will carry out a theoretical study of high-energy phenomena and will probably work
with Dr. Pevsner in this field.
"Both men will teach," said Dr.
Dieke.,
Dr. Fulton received his BA.,
M.A., and Ph.D. at Harvard. He
was awarded a Frank B. Jewett
post-doctoral fellowship to study
at the Institute of Advanced Study
in 1954- and a National Science
Foundation fellowship to continue
his work at the Institute for '55.
Dr. Pevsner received his B.A., MA.,
and Ph.D. from Columbia. He is
at present an instructor in physics
at MIT.

What young people are doing at General Electric
FRANK V. SUMMERS joined G.E. in

1949 after receiving a B.S. in Chemical Engineering at Iowa State University the same year. He also graduated from G.E.'s Process Technology
program and other specialized courses.

Young chemical
engineer works
on new ways
to make silicones
Silicones are a new class of man-made chemicals with very unusual properties. Made from
sand,they assume the form of rubber,grease,
oil and resin. Under extremes of heat and
cold, the rubber stays rubbery, the oil oily.
Silicones added to fabrics make them exceptionally water-repellent. Silicone makes
waxes spread easier,..paints almost impervious to weather.
One of the men responsible for finding new
ways to produce silicone products is 26-yearold Frank V. Summers.
Summers' Work Interesting, Important
engineer of the Silicone Products
process
As
Department, Frank Summers first compares
the results of small-scale, pilot-plant experiments with the production methods in actual
use. Then, using* his own knowledge of
chemical-engineering principles, he designs
faster, more efficient and more economical
methods of producing silicone products.
Frank Summers' excellent training, diversified experience and outstanding personal
qualifications make him a valuable contributor to this engineering team.
25,000 College Graduates at General Electric
When Frank Summers came to General
Electric in 1949, he already knew the kind
of work he wanted to do. Like each of our
25,000 college-graduate employees, he was
given his chance to grow and realize his full
potential. For General Electric has long believed this: Whenever fresh young minds are
given the freedom to make progress, everybody benefits—the individual, the company,
and the country.

Julian Huxley, Nobel inners
To Attend June Conferences

Lehigh University's trick drill team of Pershing Rifle Company
F-5, performs a non-too-perfect maneuver for the judges last Saturday on Homewood Field during the day long drill competition of
the Pershing Rifles' Fifth Regiment. Pennsylvania Military College
copped all honors in winning the meet from a field of 20 other
schools. The day's activities were topped off with a banquet and
a dance.

Eight IFB Greeks
To Donate Services
To Kids Tomorrow
Eight fraternities are participating in tomorrow's Inter-Fraternity Board Children's Softball
Tournament, stated Ron Nagler
IFB Vice-president.
Each fraternity has invited a
group of 10-12 year old boys from
various homes around the city to
spend a day as its guest. A run-off
tourney will be held in the morning from 9:45 until approximately
1 P.m. The winning group of boys
will receive an engraved trophy;
all clubs will receive small tro-

phies signifying their participation.
Interest Is High
Afterwards the fraternities will
invite their boys to the respective
houses for lunch. In the afternoon they may bring the boys to
the lacrosse game, or entertain
them in any manner which they
see fit.
Nagler stated that "the interest
has been running high." He added,
"I really appreciate the enthusiasm that has been shown by the
members of the IFB, and am sure
that we will have as much fun as
the kids."

will be presented to the symposium by Dr. H. Fraenkel-Conrat
and Dr. Robley Williams of the

Dr. G. Stanley, who won a Nobel

"The really important question
in this symposium is that there is
in the nucleic acid molecule which
causes it to show the mysterious
property of inheritability," Dr.
McElroy said. Three men from
England will join three biologists
from the United States in presenting this topic. After a presentation of the mechanism of the
cell's synthesis of the nucleic acids,
which are the acids involved in
the make-up of inheritable particles, the chemical structure of the
nucleic acids will be presented to
the symposium.
"This is one of the more exciting works in recent times—the in4

vestigation within a test tube of
the composition of these basic particles of heredity," Dr. McElroy
said. "We can't make a specific
nucleic acid yet," he said, but
he expressed the feeling of a definite possibility that this would
be accomplished.
Hopkins' Dr. H. Bentley Glass
will open the symposium's first
session, moderating the topic "The
Cellular Units of Heredity." "It
contains the presentations of several outstanding men, such as
George W. Beadle, the father of
bio-chemical genetics." Dr. Hans
Ris of the University of Wisconsin
will be among those speaking in
this all-day session. "The speakers were selected because they are
the individuals who are the experts on the topics covered," Dr.
McElroy stated.
The studies of the transforming
of one type of organism into another type has been studied extensively only in the past two or
three years. "Converting one
strain of organism into another
within a test tube is one of the
exciting new fields," he said.

Julian Huxley and several Nobel
Prize winners will be among the
scientists participating in the McCollum-Pratt Institute's symposium on the chemical basis of
heredity, which will be held here
June 19-21, Dr. William D. McElroy, director of the institute,
announced this week.
A great part of the symposium
will be devoted to the possibility
of "making" living viruses by
combining inert proteins and certain types of acids normally found
within a living cell but not possessing life in themselves.
Dr. McElroy stated that since
this process involved the apparent creation of life, he expects
the discussion to enter the realm
of philosophic definitions of life.
He said, "This is our seventh symposium, and I would say that it
will be by far the hottest."
Immunology Revolutionized
The ability to "make" viruses
could "revolutionize the field of
immunology in bacteriology," according to the biochemist. If a
virus could be synthesized which
was only slightly different from a
virus which caused a disease, and
then this man-made virus injected into a person, the person's
blood stream would buid up antibodies to protect him against the
disease-causing virus.

Lull In Schedule Jay Stickmen To Meet RPI
Seen Helping Frosh After Sinking Army At Point
Though in the midst of a two and
one half week break in the schedule, the freshman lacrosse team
Is far from taking a break in practice routine. Coach Wilson Fewster does not plan any let up.
In fact the baby Jays scrimmaged a couple of outside teams
of high repute this week, and
Fewster has two more scheduled
this week. He stated that he believed that the scrimmages should
more than compensate for any
games that would otherwise be
played, since the clubs he had arranged to scrimmage were even
better than those which the frosh
come up against in the regularly
scheduled games.
Fewster could not help but be
proud of the job the boys have
done this season. Thus far, the
yearlings have turned in a perfect slate of four victories. Even
in their worst showing of the present campaign, against Boys' Latin,
the opposition was able to get no
closer than seven goals. The Jays
took that one by an 11-4 margin.

Hofstra Hit Hard
The high spot of the season thus
far has been the Hofstra contest.
On a rainy day, with the first
string sitting out half the game,
Hopkins ran roughshod over the
visitors from Long Island by a
20-2 score. In their only other
games of the campaign, the freshmen came out on top of St. Paul's
and the Virginia freshmen.
Billy Morrill, former Friend's
School ace, leads the scoring
parade with 14 goals and 7 assists
for a total of 21 points. Mickey
Webster, Boys' Latin alumnus, is
a close second with 11 goals and 7
assists for 18 points; Bruce Duffaney, the third member of the
starting attack, has tossed in eight
goals, and assisted four others.
Low Scoring Opposition
Billy Powell is right behind Duffaney and leads the midfields in
scoring with seven goals and four
assists. Eddie Bernstein has five
goals and five assists to his credit
while Al Seivold has scored three
times and has been involved in
the
six other goals. As a team
sixty

Top Defensive Effort
"This was our top defensive effort of the season," commented
Scott. "Dick Watts, Bob Burgess
and Walt Mitchell held the Cadet
attack unit to only one goal and
itole the ball from the host team
on several occasions."
Scott praised his two midfield
units for their drive, defensive
play and ball control. The Jay
mentor was very pleased with the
way in which his second unit
played against the taller Cadets.
Arlyn Marshall was lauded for his

leadership, and scoring.
When asked how he felt about
the win over Army, the Jay mentor
replied, "This was our most cherished victory of the season thus
far, since Army ha's a fine team
which had defeated Princeton by
a 10-3 count. Our squad played
its best game of the season and
I am proud of everyone. We outhustled the Cadets and controlled
the loose balls."
Scott Lauds Squad
"Our defense displayed the best
riding of the year," Scott stated,
"which caused the West Point
defense to fail to clear the ball
on several occasions. Marshall and
White controlled the faceoffs,
while the attack unit of Jory, Bennett and Breslau did very well."

With all its remaining games
being Conference affairs, the Hopkins baseball team will be pointing for its third win tomorrow against Washington College

defeated Navy, and were defeated

wild pitching and a few errors
they lost their fifth game of the
season. Sam Liko collected three
nd Loren Cox garnered two of
'the Bird's hits.
Coach Ross Sachs commented,
'the Gettysburg game was the
orst of the season. It all started
n the first inning when they got
wo doubles off of Radek. Our
itchers just didn't have it. They
'aye up eleven walks, hit two baters and threw two wild pitches.

walks.

in the seventh the score was 4-3
and I put in Oursler who made the
next three batters hit grounders,
but an error on a double play ball
proved clostly and they scored
four runs in that inning."
Wednesday the Jays met the
Terrors of Western Maryland on
the Homewood Field in a MasonDixon Conference tilt and tomorrow Washington College furnishes
the opposition in another conference game.
Coach Sachs says, "we can play
better ball than we did last week.
With our next five games being
Mason-Dixon games we should
do fairly well if we can get more
coordination between our pitchers
and our hitters.

'50 Stick Team
'Presents Award'
A new lacrosse award will be
given beginning this year, according to James F. Adams, co-captain of the 1950 Hopkins stick
squad.
The award, to be presented to
the senior lacrosse player who has
shown the most improvement during his years on the Hopkins team,
will be donated by the members of
the 1950 lacrosse team.
The recipient of the award will
be selected by the vote of a committee which will be comprised of
the members of the 1950 team, including Bob Scott and Wilson
Fewster, Dr. W. Kelso Morrill, director of student activities, and
Dr. G. Wilson Shaffer, dean of the
Homewood Schools.
A plaque, containing an inscription and the name- of the selected
player, will be given to the player
and a replica placed on permanent display in the school.

Darlene Graves of Cherry Hill admires the project that copped
first prize in Division I of the Baltimore Science Fair at Hopkins.
The fair was sponsored by the Hopkins in cooperation with the North
Baltimore Kiwanis Club. The winners will be sent to the National
Science Fair to be held in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, May 10 through
12. The project "Cationic Analysis of the Mouse" was prepared by
Jack Maniloff of Forest Park High School.

Theodore W.Palmer was elected
to head the Hopkins chapter of
the Students For Democratic Action for 1956-57 at a meeting of
SDA held last Monday.
Tony Adona was chosen as vicepresident; Turpin Rose as Secretary-treasurer. Palmer said of his
plans, "I intend to put out an
Issue of the Bulletin during Orientation Week; the membership has
to be increased in order that we
may engage in political action as
is our aim. I intend to make a
concerted effort to obtain new
members during
Orientation."
Palmer felt that the main concern of SDA should be civil rights,
but most of the activity of the
Hopkins chapter next year probably will "center around elections.
I feel that a liberal organization
at the present time must face the
problem of changing racial patterns in the United States and
attempt to see that the weakness
engendered by the present racial
tension is resolved."
